analytic.title: L’antica versione siriaca dei Vangeli dopo centocinquant’anni di ricerca

biblStruct.note: This paper shows the status quaestionis about some aspects of the old Syriac version of the Gospels. The Syriac Church used two ways to spread the Gospels: Tatianus' Diatessaron (175 a. C.), and the Mepharreshe, that is the Separated Gospels, handed down by two manuscripts, the Curetonian and the Syrosinaiticus, dated IV-V century. In the most diffused present opinion the two manuscripts can be two different recensions of the Old Syriac version. The Syrosinaiticus seems to be the oldest witness in spite of a long transmission process. The Old Syriac version is generally considered later and partly depending on the Diatessaron; it can go back to the early III century even if some questions are still unsolved. Such a version shows some traces of expressions deriving from various authors differently and it is the subject of one of the most interesting debates about the origins of Christianity.
